etymologies: late 16th century; earliest use found in John Higgins (b. c1544), poet and linguist. From classical Latin verberāt-, past participial stem of verberāre to flog, to lash, to strike repeatedly, to batter from verbera (plural) instrument for flogging, blows administered in flogging, lashes, (in singular) blow, stroke in general from the same Indo-European base as Old Church Slavonic vrbě (locative singular), Old Russian verba (Russian verba) willow, Lithuanian virbas twig, rod

definitions: To strike (something) so as to produce a sound; to cause to reverberate or resound; to generate or emanate (sound) in this way.
Of a sound: to echo, resound, reverberate.
